subtitle: [Music]
New Thinking
Allowed. Conversations on the leading edge
of knowledge and discovery. With
parapsychologist
Jeffery Mishlove.
Hello, and welcome. I’m Jeffrey
Mishlove. Today
I'm going to return to the list of
questions that was posted by viewers
from our
YouTube Live Stream that took place on
October
11th. The truth is I still have more than
pages of questions that I haven't yet
addressed so
it could keep me going for quite a while.
MW says, "I'm a huge
Robert Anton Wilson fan. Could you please
share some memories
of meeting and befriending the late
discordian pope?"
Yes, I knew Bob Wilson quite well going
back to the days
in which we both lived in Berkeley,
California and
hung out really with the same group of
people. I knew Bob, I knew his wife
Arlen,
I met their daughter Luna who was
sadly murdered on the streets of
Berkeley
. As I recall they had
her body, at least her head, I think
it was frozen
in the hope that she could be revived
someday. I'll share another
memory. One day I was standing
on a street corner, I think it might have
been
Shattuck Avenue and
Bancroft, something like that in
Berkeley and Bob
happened to walk up just
coincidentally at the same street corner.
I said hello to him and I said, "Oh, Bob
I've been expecting you.
" And he looked at me, his eyes were wide
open. I was joking but
he thought I was serious, that somehow
synchronistically I knew he would be
there
. I thought that was a funny moment.
Travis Smith says,
"I got abducted by aliens and implanted
and now
I can remote view. I hate it. What do you
think about the human rights violation
caused by these interactions with the
sentient one?" You know what,
Travis,
I can't tell if you're responding
tongue-in-cheek or seriously.
But in any case, it is
to abduct people, to rape people anally
as Whitley Strieber claims. He still
takes
medication because of some sort of an
anal probe. It's a violation
as far as I'm concerned. It is a
violation and I don't quite agree with
Whitley when he says, you know, we
should
enter into a state of communion with
these
beings who are violating our rights. It
almost sounds
like what you hear from people who
have been subjected to abuse.
"skulpcha" asks,
"In spite of the overwhelming evidence
collected by Dr.
Ian Stevenson, the late Dr. Ian Stevenson
on reincarnation being the machinery of
the universe, why have scientists
not taken the phenomenon seriously?"
Very good question skulpcha.
I would have to say the reason is
because
most scientists implicitly
accept the materialistic paradigm
upon which our technology is based.
It's sort of the implicit paradigm
behind the bedrock of sciences, physics.
Well you see, I don't think
physics should be the bedrock of
sciences, but since it's considered to be
such and since
it is based on the idea of materialism
scientists who subscribe to that
world view
just have very little room
in their consciousness for dealing
with
reincarnation. So, ultimately I think it's the
materialistic paradigm
that needs to be seriously challenged,
the way people like Bernardo Kastrup, who
has been interviewed
many times on New Thinking Allowed have
done.
Jip Atkinson asks,
"When will you do another karaoke video,
Jeffrey?" My thinking about it is, Jip,
that I'd like to do at least one more
before the
end of the year. I'm thinking maybe to
celebrate the holidays.
It even occurred to me, I wonder if
it's possible
to have some kind of a group
karaoke event, a live stream where
viewers could contribute
karaoke as well. I don't know how that
could be done but
it's a thought, it's an interesting
thought. I bet I'm not the only one
who enjoys karaoke.
The RFM says,
"Do you think there is a way for a
Nietzschean
split of society, alla Übermensch
and Untermenschen that doesn't abandon
a Christian morality structure, where
those with the will to power
lend a hand to the meek?"
Gee, that's a fascinating question.
Do I think there's a way for that to
happen?
You know, I imagine that there is.
It's not really the way
I think of things. I don't normally think
in Nietzschean terms and I don't
normally
think in sociological terms very often.
But when it does come to
society I'm a very
big follower of the writings of the
sociologist Pitirim
Sorokin. In fact I will be,
probably before this "In Presence"
monologue is released, you will have
heard
my discussion about Sorokin's
great book, The Ways and Power of Love.
Sorokin advocates
something along the lines that you're
describing there.
I'm in favor of anything that
Sorokin advocates, I really am.
Vani B says,
"I'm in chemo for Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma.
Is there a guided spiritual imagery you
can recommend?"
Yes, Vani we have posted a guided
imagery meditation and I'm going to link
to it right now. In fact, we posted a
few
so I'm going to link to
at least two different guided
meditations for healing.
I hope they help you.
James Preval says, "Imagine a world where
advanced ET technology was recovered,
back engineered, kept secret from the
public for over half a century
and were to be disclosed to the public
tomorrow
. What would happen
if we had a massive disclosure
tomorrow
regarding ET technology?" Well,
I think most people would go about their
lives. Most people
are not concerned about major advances
in technology. Most people are concerned
with
bread and butter issues.
So, I’m personally under the opinion that
if such
a revelation were to occur society would
adjust
. It would take a long time. There would be
a group of people who are on top of it
right away and it would gradually
filter down into society
and we deal with it. It doesn't seem
all that extraordinary to me actually.
Peter Sheamus Gunn
asks, "Would you, in the circumstance of
having the ability to assassinate
a tyrannical murderous dictator
responsible for the ongoing deaths of
many thousands of people ever make that
choice?" What a fascinating
question, Peter.
I have to tell you I probably
wouldn't
make that choice because I don't know
that I have it in me
to assassinate anybody.
So I'm probably not the right person to
ask
. You know what else, I don't believe
that violence is the answer. I think
violence just begets violence. You could
assassinate
this person and that person. It might
have a temporary
effect but in the long run you're
contributing to the violence
in society. I would prefer to find
non-violent means whenever
possible. You know,
it's a question as a conscientious
objector we often
get asked things like this, what would
you do if you saw somebody raping your
mother
and you had a gun and you could stop
them?
Would you violate your own
principles in that circumstance? Well,
you know a lot of people would violate
their own principles in such a
circumstance.
Nevertheless, it's a good thing
to live
by, principles, and some of these
extreme
examples that sort of goad people into
getting
angry and feeling the dark side of the
force,
I don't know. I think we can do better.
Let's move on here.
Marshall McLuhan asks, "How
does one find meaning?
" Great question. I always enjoyed the
advice of my old late friend
Huston Smith who I've interviewed many
times, the author of
The World's Religions.
His attitude was the closer you get to
God
the more meaningful everything becomes.
I just love that phrase. It seems
to me there's something to it.
The irony is that for many people it's
like the closer you get to power
the more meaningful everything becomes.
Somehow I think that that's an
illusion, that
the people who seek meaning in
power are going to be disappointed at
the end.
On the other hand it may well be that
God is just as much an illusion.
But I think it's a more enticing
illusion.
Bottom line, I'm probably
something of an agnostic
with regard to God and yet I
find great inspiration
in Huston Smith's thought about looking
there for meaning.
Now, another way to think of meaning is
what the existentialists
say, we create our own meaning. It's up to
you
not to find meaning, to make meaning.
I suppose it's true in my own life,
that's what I'm doing, that's what I'm
doing right this second
here and in general over the past
many years with the New Thinking Allowed
channel.
Salvador Morphin writes,
"How sure are you that we have free will,
being beings composed of synapses that
are programmed to pass recollection
influenced by macro and micro
probabilities?
Could free will be an illusion?" Salvador,
yes it could be an
illusion, but it's a very strong illusion.
There are different ways to define free
will. Obviously,
there are many sources of influence
upon
our behavior, physical, biological,
sociological
psychological, we're under all of those
influences.
But none of them are necessarily
definitive, except you know, we have to
breathe.
We have to have water. There's certain
things that we cannot live
without. But I think I like the
definition of free will that says, if
you're
taking an action of your own choice
nobody is forcing you to take
that action. Then you might as well
consider it free will,
regardless of what other causal factors
might be
involved. Well,
because this is an ‘In Presence"
monologue and I like to keep them
generally speaking under 15 minutes,
I'm going to close now. But I still have
over 30 pages
of questions so I plan to come back.
Let me say a couple of things though in
closing
. One of them is that we have a
free weekly newsletter for New Thinking
Allowed viewers. It contains
all sorts of information I think you
will find both informative
and inspiring and it also includes
previews of the
videos to be released in the upcoming
week.
You can subscribe for free by going to
our
foundation, new thinking allowed
dot org [newthinkingallowed.org], and remember allowed is
spelled a l l o w e d and new thinking
allowed
is all one word.
But let me leave you with a question
for yourself. The question that Marshall
McLuhan
posed, how did you find meaning
in your life? Thank you
for being with me.
[Music]
